loans.name: Vilma

texts.en:
Vilma G. is a farmer. She lives in the community of Banga, South Cotabato. She also raises pigs and chickens. She wants to improve her livelihood and have a bigger farm someday.

With 10 years experience, it is her hope to continue her business and earn a bigger income for her family. She needs this loan to be able to buy fertilizers and seeds. The profit from her business will help buy the basic needs for their family.

loans.use: to buy fertilizers and seeds

loans.name: Isabel

texts.en:
Goals are nothing unless one makes the effort to meet them. Isabel D., 49, knows this, and gives her best to accomplish the goals she has set for her and her family. 

She is married to Oscar D., 59, who is a cook for their own food vending business. They have six children, with one attending college now. Isabel’s family resides in Ascoville, Malaria, Caloocan City.

Isabel currently runs a sari-sari (variety) store that caters to needs that are more immediate than the nearest grocery in the community. Isabel has operated her variety store from home for years now, along with her food vending business. With the help of her husband as cook, they cook and sell viand, delicacies to accompany rice, which are usually present in Filipino homes every meal time. 

Serving their community with these businesses, they gained regular customers who keep her businesses alive. She employs no one and earns an estimated income of PHP 6,000 a month.

To help Isabel continue operation of her businesses, she is requesting a PHP 12,000 loan. She will use this to buy additional stock for her store and more raw ingredients like meats, vegetables and sacks of rice for her food vending business. She will see to it that her store will not lack any valuable thing that her customers need, so that they will make her their number one sari-sari store in the community.

Isabel has learned the value of improving one’s business, and thus works to innovate hers. She does not emphasize any problem she encounters but rather focuses on its solution. Goals cannot be met just by identifying the problem, but by acting on them. The most important goal she has in mind is to support her children until their college graduation, with which she will feel most fulfilled.

*All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To purchase additional products for her variety store and raw ingredients needed for her food vending business

loans.name: Elsita

texts.en:

To make a living, Elsita owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop, selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap, canned goods, snack foods and toothpaste in the local community. Elsita has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month.

In 2010, Elsita joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her business and living situation. Elsita has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional inventory and for working capital. 

Elsita is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell like  snack foods and canned goods. This will be the second loan taken out by Elsita from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the loan to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:
HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Araceli

texts.en:
Araceli A., 50, is married to a farmer and has four children, one girl and three boys. 

To make a living, she grows rice for sale. She also grows vegetables at her farm. Aside from that, her family has a small piggery in their backyard and sells "ukay-ukay" (used clothes). Araceli works hard to provide the needs of her family.

Araceli is in need of additional fertilizer and feed. She has applied for a loan of 14,000 PHP from Kiva partner, CEVI. She is hopeful that this loan will help improve her harvest.

loans.use: To purchase additional fertilizers and feed

loans.name: Sumitra

texts.en:
In the Kathmandu Valley, clothing is made to order. Tailor stalls line the streets where store owners sell material and work their sewing machines.  These skilled tailors make school uniforms for children as well as the the traditional women's kurta surwal and men's daura surwal. 

This is 40 year-old Sumitra B.. She is married and has one child, aged 1. In 2000, she established her tailoring business. Working seven days a week and seven hours a day, she supports her family.  

With a Kiva loan, BPW borrowers like Sumitra are able to purchase additional cloth material or sewing machines that will increase production and profitability. Sumitra has already received and successfully repaid a loan from Patan BPW. She is using her most recent loan to buy materials for her tailoring work.  

In the future, Sumitra plans to uplift the economic condition of her family. She thanks you for your support.  

This loan was administered by Kiva's local partner microfinance institution, Patan Business and Professional Women. Patan BPW became Kiva's first field partner in Nepal in 2007. Patan BPW operates throughout the Kathmandu Valley, offering microcredit and business training programs to low-income women. In addition to providing economic opportunity to their clients, Patan BPW seeks to empower Nepali women within the home and community. For more information about Patan BPW, visit our BPW Partner Page and keep an eye out for new loans and borrower updates. Join our lending team: BPW Lending Team

loans.use: To buys materials for her tailoring business

loans.name: Edeliza

texts.en:
Edeliza U. is from the village of Toril. She is 47 years old. Edeliza is married and has four adult children. 

To make a living, Edeliza owns and operates a hog fattening business. Edeliza has been engaged in her business for over eight years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month.

In 2003, Edeliza joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her business and living situation. Edeliza has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from PMPC. 

Edeliza is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase livestock feed and other supplies. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income. 

About PMPC:
Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase livestock feed and other supplies

loans.name: Elsa

texts.en:
Elsa B. is from the village of Talisayan, Misamis Oriental. She is 39 years old. Elsa is married and has three school children. To make a living, Elsa owns and operates a business making and selling food. The main source of income for the business comes from making and selling snacks and other delicacies like banana and camote (or sweet potato) cue in the local community. Elsa has been engaged in her business for over eight years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for these activities. In 2010, Elsa joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Elsa has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used as working capital and to purchase additional ingredients. Elsa is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase raw ingredients she needs, like bananas and sugar. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Elsa from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand it.

About HSPFI:
HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase raw ingredients needed like bananas & sugar

loans.name: Engelen

texts.en:
Engelen A., 27, is from the village of Datu Tangkilan and a group member of PMPC. She is married with three children, two students and one infant. To make a living, Engelen owns and operates a sari-sari (retail) store selling products for daily consumption.

In 2010, Engelen joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP to add to her capital and inventory. This will be her first loan from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her family's general living conditions. 

About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To use as capital and purchase inventory for her sari-sari (retail) store.

location.town: Datu Tangkilan, Sindangan, Zamboanga del Norte

loans.name: Elena

texts.en:
Elena E., 53, is married to a farmer. She owns and operates a business venture in the agricultural sector planting and harvesting rice and vegetables. In addition, to support her family needs, she runs a sari-sari store and also sells "ukay-ukay" (used clothes). Elena works hard to support the studies of her three beautiful daughters. 

Elena is in need of additional fertilizer and capital for her store. She applied for a loan of 15,000 PHP from Kiva partner CEVI. She is hopeful that this loan will help improve her harvest and store.

loans.use: To purchase additional fertilizers and merchandise to sell.

loans.name: Lucresia

texts.en:
Lucresia T., 57, is from the village of Talinga and is a group member of PMPC. She is married and has two children. To make a living, Lucresia owns and operates a sari-sari (general) store in the local community. Her customers are neighbors and people in the nearby Barangays.

In 2007, Lucresia joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP to add to her capital. This will be her fourth loan from PMPC. Lucresia plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her family's general living conditions. 

About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. loans.use: Additional capital to buy products.

location.town: Talinga, Leon B. Postigo, Zamboanga del Norte

loans.name: Marcelina

texts.en:
Marcelina U., 73, is from the village of Toril. She is married and has two adult children. To make a living, Marcelina owns and operates a hog fattening business. The main source of income for the business comes from raising pigs for sale. She has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 2,000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2000, Marcelina joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan from PMPC. Marcelina is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP to purchase baby livestock to raise and sell. This will be her 12th loan from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement her family's income. 

About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase baby livestock to raise and sell.

loans.name: Sarswati

texts.en:
Sarswati T., 49, is married and has three children, aged 23, 27 and 29. In 2000, she established her vegetable farming business. Working seven days a week and four hours a day, she supports her family. She has already received and successfully repaid one loan from Patan BPW, which she used to buy seeds and fertilizer for vegetable farming. In the future, Sarswati plans to uplift the economic condition of her family. She thanks you for your support.

Over 70% of Nepal's economy is agricultural. Typically, Nepali households grow crops on small plots of terraced land. Rice (bhat), lentils (daal) and vegetables (thakari) are the staples of the Nepali diet. With a Kiva loan, BPW's borrowers are able to purchase greater amounts of seed and fertilizer.  With more seeds and fertilizer, a borrower is able to grow cash crops to be sold in the local market. Such crops allow households to move beyond subsistence and provide much-needed cash income throughout the year. 

This loan was administered by Kiva's local partner MFI, Patan Business and Professional Women. Patan BPW became Kiva's first field partner in Nepal in 2007.  Patan BPW operates throughout the Kathmandu Valley, offering microcredit and business training programs to low-income women. In addition to providing economic opportunity to their clients, Patan BPW seeks to empower Nepali women within the home and community. For more information about Patan BPW, visit our partner page and keep an eye out for new loans and borrower updates and join our lending team, BPW Lending Team.

loans.use: To buy seed and fertilizer.

loans.name: Evelyn

texts.en:
We do not need to make a lot of mistakes before we get to learn. At the age of 54, Evelyn learns the ways of both business and life to get going at a better pace. She finished her high school education but her training in CCT* as a Community Partner enables her to run a business with confidence. She is married to Rodolfo T., a foreman. They live in Malaria, Caloocan City along with their two children, who are in high school.

Evelyn has been in the direct selling business for three years and is still doing her best to master her trade. She tries to figure out what her customers like when it comes to bags, shoes, shirts and pants. With no employees to help her sell, Evelyn gives her utmost strength to make her business work. She earns an estimated income of 8,000 PHP per month.

To help her grow her business, Evelyn is requesting a loan of 8,000 PHP. She will use the loan to buy quality apparel to make sure that her customers get only the best in the market, as well as purchase those items ordered in advance by her customers. With this money on hand, she can easily improve her business, one lesson she learned in her fellowship* with fellow community partners.

Just like any micro entrepreneur, Evelyn also suffers from customers who do not pay their debts. Still, as she learns how to be a successful entrepreneur, she also learns how to deal with such difficult times in business. The simplest dreams she has in her heart is for her family to have good health and to see her children graduate from college.

*All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To purchase inventory and stocks ordered in advance by customers.

loans.name: Emelita

texts.en:
Married to a driver, Emelita A., 57, owns and operates a business venture in the agricultural sector harvesting jackfruit in her backyard. She has a small store that sells Barquillos, thin-rolled cookies of Spanish origin. Emelita works hard to improve the standard of living of her family and meet the needs of her four children, two girls and two boys.

Emelita is in need of additional capital for her store. She has applied for a loan of 14,000 PHP from Kiva partner CEVI. She is hopeful that this loan will help her to improve her store.

loans.use: To invest in expanding her business.

loans.name: Helen

texts.en:
Helen O., 52, is from the village of Duka, Medina, Misamis Oriental. She is married and has two adult children. To make a living, Helen runs a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. The main source of income for the business comes from buying and selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap, canned goods, snack foods, biscuits, detergents and toothpaste in the local community. Helen has been engaged in her business for over 30 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2009, Helen joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Helen has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP which she used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. She is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP to purchase additional products to sell such as snack foods and canned goods. This will be her fourth loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell, such as snack foods and canned goods.

loans.name: Roseminda

texts.en:
Roseminda S., 50, is from the village of Maras and is a group member of PMPC. She is married and has nine children, two of whom are still studying while the rest already have their own families. To make a living, Roseminda owns a motorcycle transport business which is being operated by her friend. Her main source of income comes from the quarterly income of her farm.

In 2008, Roseminda joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Roseminda is requesting a new loan of 23,000 PHP which will be used to start a new business. This will be her fourth loan from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve her family's general living conditions. 

About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.name: Delma

texts.en:
Delma S., 34, is from the village of Makawa. She is married and has five school-aged children. To make a living, Delma owns and operates a fish selling business. The main source of income for the business comes from selling a variety of fish in the local community. Delma has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month from this activity. 

In 2006, Delma joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan from PMPC. Delma is requesting a new loan of 6,000 PHP to purchase additional inventory and use as working capital. This will be her seventh loan from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to financially support her immediate family.

About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

loans.name: Claudia

texts.en:
Claudia A. is from the village of Santiago, Gingoog City. She is 59 years old. Claudia is married and has 8 adult-aged children. To make a living, Claudia owns and operates a specialized retail store. The main source of income for the business comes from buying and selling firewood and wood-related products in the local community. She is also running a retail store selling snack foods and canned goods. Claudia has been engaged in her business for over 2 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Claudia joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Claudia has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional inventory and increase working capital. Claudia is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell, like firewood. This will be the 5th loan taken out by Claudia from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. loans.name: Hanily

texts.en:
Hanily E., 48 years old, is married to a driver. She has 3 children; 2 girls and 1 boy. She owns a small store that sells shoes and bags. She also maintains a small vegetable garden in her backyard. Hanily works hard to save for her own house and lot, and to support the needs of her family.

Hanily is in need of additional capital to expand her business. She applied for a loan of 13,000 PHP from Kiva partner, CEVI. She is hopeful that this loan will help her reach her dream to have a house of their own.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Lida

texts.en:
If one would dream for one’s self or one’s family, why not dream for the best? Lida B., 48, dreams for the best, but more than that, she acts to make it a reality. Lida is married to Jimmy B., a factory worker. They have three children who are now in elementary, high school, and college. Together, they live in Malaria, Caloocan City. 

Lida has taken vocational courses. With the learning she gains as a Community Partner in CCT*, Lida runs her own sari-sari (variety) store to capitalize on the big target market she has in her community. She has been doing business here for seven years. It is quite easy for her since it is a residential business, and there is not much need at present to hire employees. She earns an estimated net income of 500 PHP per day.

To help grow her store, Lida is requesting a 22,000 PHP loan. She plans to use the funds to buy more grocery items to put in her store, so that it won’t look bare and incomplete. Lida makes an effort to maintain her business in good shape, because a profitable business translates to family needs being met and the schooling of her children being supported. 

Lida struggles with time management when it comes to balancing business, health and family life. However, she sees to it that these struggles will not prevent her from reaching her dreams for her family. She desires to see her small store grow and eventually expand. She dreams of having good health for everyone in the family and being able to send her children all the way through college. Deep inside, she knows that if there is faith, and action, everything will be possible.

With her going to CCT fellowship* meeting every week, she was able to improve and enjoy her relationship with God. As a Christian, through the Word of God, she also gained strength and inspiration day after day.
	
*All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: additional stocks for her variety store

loans.name: Lilian

texts.en: Forty-two-year-old Lilian Z. is married to a meat vendor and has two children, a girl and a boy. She owns and operates a small piggery in their backyard. Also, she runs a sari-sari (variety) store and sells chorizos to her friends and neighbors. Lilian works hard to expand their small business and provide a decent living for her family. Lilian is in need of additional piglets for her piggery. She applied for a loan of 15,000 Philippines pesos (PHP) from Kiva partner CEVI. She is hopeful that this loan will help her expand her business.

loans.use: To purchase additional piglets to grow

loans.name: Jona

texts.en:
Jona T. is 44 years old, married, and has two school-aged children.  She lives in the village of San Jose, Medina, Misamis Oriental. To make a living, Jona owns and operates a specialized retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from buying and selling green and yellow bananas in the local community. Jona has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month.

In 2010, Jona joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Jona has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI, which was used to to purchase additional inventory and acquire working capital. Jona is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional bananas to sell. This loan will be Jona's second loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

She is applying for this loan for 7,000 PHP to buy additional fertilizer and seeds, and believes that this loan will help her improve her harvest and with it, her income.

In 2009, Elsa joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her life and ability to engage in business. She has successfully repaid two previous loans and is applying for a new one to expand her business.

About PMPC:
Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

loans.name: Mercedes

texts.en: Mercedes C. has four children, one girl and three boys, and makes a living by running a sari-sari (or variety) store where she sells various items such as sugar, vinegar and soy sauce. She works hard to provide her precious children with a decent life, and is applying for this loan for 9,000 PHP to expand her business by buying more items to sell to her customers.

loans.name: Noel

texts.en:
Noel R. lives in the village of Bacungan. He is 36 years old, married, and makes a living by selling fish. He has been in this line of work for more than one year and makes about 15,000 PHP a month. 

In 2008, Alberto joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve his life and ability to engage in business. He is applying for his third loan, for 20,000 PHP, to expand his business and improve his family's living conditions. 

About PMPC:
Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

location.town: Leon B. Postigo, Zamboanga del Norte

loans.name: Nenita

texts.en: Nenita A., 55, received training as an accountant in college and applies her academic training in the sari-sari (or variety) store she runs. Her husband works overseas while she lives in San Jose Del Monte, Bulacan with their one child, who is employed and uses his income to help support the family. Nenita earns about 350 PHP a day and is applying for a loan for 10,000 PHP to buy more goods to sell to her customers. A faithful CCT community partner, she attends our weekly meetings, where members study the bible, build social capital and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to buy more items to sell to her customers

loans.name: Ruth

texts.en:
Ruth D. is married to a seaman and has three children. She owns and operates a business venture in the agricultural sector running a small piggery in their backyard. She also maintains a small cassava farm and makes barquillios, a thin-rolled cookie that is popular in the Philippines.

Ruth needs additional pig feeds and vitamins and is requesting a loan of 15,000 PHP from Kiva partner, CEVI.

loans.use: To purchase additional pig feeds and vitamins

loans.name: Pel

texts.en: The woman the picture is Pel C., 40 years old, who lives in the province of Kompong Cham. Pel C. owns a small store next to her house, which is full of people, and she uses this store to sell breakfast and lunch foods. She generates a profit of approximately US$ 2 a day to help support her family’s daily expenses with more stability. Her husband is a horse cart driver in and around his community. This couple has four teenage children. Pel C. will be using her loan to build a new bathroom for the whole family to use because her old one has broken down. That is why Pel C. would like to request a loan from Kiva in order to have her family live a comfortable life.

loans.use: To build a new bathroom for the family.

loans.name: Randy

texts.en:
Randy F. is 24 years old, married, and has one child.  He lives in Pangarap Village, Caloocan City.  He has a college education and currently operates a sari-sari (variety) store, which caters to needs that are more immediate than the nearest grocery in the community. Randy has run his store from from home for two years and has gained regular customers who keep his business alive. He earns an estimated net income of 7,000 PHP a month.

Because his goal is to increase his business, he is requesting a loan of 10,000 PHP, which he will use to buy goods that his customers prefer. He will see to it that his store will not lack any valuable thing that his customers need, so that they will make his sari-sari store their first choice in the community.

Randy knows the value of improving one’s business, and thus works to innovate his. He does not emphasize any problem he encounters but rather focuses on its solution. Goals cannot be met just by identifying the problem, but by acting on them. One most important goal he has in mind is to support his child until college graduation.

As a Christian believer, Randy believes that everything will be possible if you have that faith in God and put this faith in action.  He faithfully attends their weekly fellowship* meeting in CCT.

*All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To purchase sacks of rice and other stock for his variety store

loans.name: Sun

texts.en: Mr. Sun S. is a 30-year-old married man who makes and sells furniture. His main products are beds and cabinets, which he makes and sells as sets. He makes the furniture primarily from wood and rattan. His wife is a local farmer. Both of them contribute their earnings to pay the family's daily expenses. The couple has two children, both of whom are in school. When school ends for the day, they help their parents make furniture. In order to increase his income, Mr. Sun S. has applied for a 500 USD loan to buy wood in order to make beds.

loans.use: To buy wood

loans.name: Leodaliza

texts.en:
Leodaliza C. is from the village of Claveria, Misamis Oriental. She is 32 years old. Leodaliza is married and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Leodaliza owns & operates a business venture in the retail sector running a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from buying and selling daily-use products such as shampoo, soap, canned goods,snack foods, biscuits, detergents & toothpaste in the local community. Leodaliza has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 12000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Leodaliza joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Leodaliza has successfully repaid a previous loan of 16000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional inventory & working capital. Leodaliza is requesting a new loan of 21000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell, like canned goods & snack foods. This loan will be the 8th loan taken out by Leodaliza from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell, like canned goods & snack foods

loans.name: Aris Setya Wiguna Group

texts.en:
I Putu R. as the leader of Aris Setya Wiguna, and he successfully leads the group very well. He was assigned to find a job carving wood for members of the group, divide the work and provide salaries appropriate to the work undertaken by its members. For this loan, members plan to buy the raw materials of wood, sand and cement.
The financial advantage gained from every job Putu gets is used for their children's school fees. For everyday needs, Putu is assisted by his wife who has a stall business. Every month I Putu R. spends on electricity costs for Rp.70.000 and meal costs amounted to Rp. 300,000.

loans.use: purchasing wood, sand and cement for purposes of business

loans.name: Peou

texts.en:
Cultivating rice is part of 30-year-old Peou S.’s daily routine. Rice is an essential product that is vital to Cambodian people. She learned to do this from her grandmother and she has been very widely known in this sector for years. 

Currently, she lives with her mother, who is a local farmer also. On the other hand, Peou S. also raises a few cows at home to generate extra profit. Peou S. will be using the loan to buy two cows to raise for future sale when they are big enough.

loans.use: To buy two cows to raise for future sale when they are big enough

loans.name: Felisa

texts.en:
We do not need to make a lot of mistakes before we get to learn. At the age of 44, Felisa, learns the ways of both business and life in order to improve herself.   She is married to Terlito I., an auto mechanic.  They live in Malaria, Caloocan City.

Felisa has been managing their auto repair shop for 15 years.  She also partners with Terlito as an auto mechanic.  They have no other employees, so  Felisa gives her utmost strength to make her business work. She earns an estimated net income of around Php700 per day.

To help her grow her business, Felisa is requesting a Php10,000 loan. She will use this money to buy a motor engine and other spare parts needed to continue operation of their auto repair shop. With this money on hand she can easily improve her business, a lesson she got in her fellowship with fellow community partners.

The simplest dream she has in her heart is for everyone in the family to have good health, and to see  more customers who will prefer their services and eventually bring growth for her business.  As CCT community partner, she is faithfully attending their weekly fellowship* meeting where she can also draw strength and inspiration received from the Word of God. 

*All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: For a motor engine and other spare parts needed for auto repair

loans.name: Kong

texts.en: Kong R., 50, is a rice dealer in the local market of her Takeo province. She is married with two children who are still living at home.  She and her husband work growing rice and raising animals. She typically makes US$7 of profit each day, and would like a loan to expand her business. In order to increase her profit, she is asking for US$1200 to purchase a stock of rice to resell. (Kong R. is pictured with her husband from home)

loans.use: To buy rice to resell

loans.name: Heang

texts.en: Heang V., 24, was married many years ago to Chanthy, age 31, and they currently earn their daily income by working in the garment factory. The couple always gets a specific salary every month and they use it to send all their kids to school and to cover their family’s daily living expenses. Currently, Heang V. wishes to buy a new motorcycle for driving to her work location in the province of Kompong Chhnang. Previously, she always rented a motor taxi to get to work because she doesn’t have her own vehicle. Therefore, she hopes to reduce the amount she spends on transportation by using her loan to purchase a motorbike.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike for driving to her work location

loans.name: Cheng

texts.en: Cheng L., 41, is married and resides with her two children in Kampong Chnang province, Cambodia, an area known for palm products. Cheng is a teacher at a public school, earning an income of USD 2 per day. Her husband sells groceries, earning an income of USD 5 per day to help cover the family expenses. Each month, the family has to spend USD 80 on food and USD 40 on the other necessary expenses. Cheng is requesting a loan of USD 1000 to purchase a motorbike for her husband to start a new business as a motor-taxi driver. In the future, she would like to use the additional income to repair her house. This will be her sixth loan from CREDIT, a long standing Kiva’s partner.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike for her husband to start a new business

loans.name: Bun

texts.en: Bun S., 40, is a widowed farmer who lives with her young child in the Takeo province. She is also makes and sells brooms, and typically makes US$5 of profit every day.  Bun would like a loan to expand her business. In order to increase her profit, she is asking for US$400 to raise cows and purchase rice to resell.

loans.use: Raise cows and sell rice.

loans.name: Phen

texts.en: Phen H., 56, is married and lives with three of her children in Takeo province. She and her husband are farmers who typically make about US$1 each day and are supported by one child working in the garment factory. The weather conditions have been difficult for farming in Cambodia this past year, and inflation has also been out of control. These factors have played into a difficult economic year for many Cambodians, Phen H. included. In light of these economic difficulties, she is asking for a loan of US$300 to purchase fertilizer and raise pigs. She is confident that this loan will allow her to increase her daily income and to better support her family.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer and raise pigs.

loans.name: Him

texts.en: Him P., 51, is married and lives with four of her children in Takeo province. She and her husband are farmers who typically make about US$2 each day and are supported by three children working in the garment factory with an income of US$3 each. The weather conditions have been difficult for farming in Cambodia this past year, and inflation has also been out of control. These factors have played into a difficult economic year for many Cambodians, Him P. included. In light of these economic difficulties, she is asking for a loan of US$600 to raise cows. She is confident that this loan will allow her to increase her daily income and to better support her family.

loans.use: Raise cows.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Raise cows.

loans.name: Pao

texts.en:
Pao R. has been in the farming business for a long time.  She plants rice crops on her own farmland which she inherited from her grandmother. In addition to the farming business, she is also employed at private organization for extra income. She has a partner in her husband, who earns income from cultivating rice crops and  from his employment as a construction worker.  This couple has two children, who are sewing workers in the garment industry in Phnom Penh City.  

Pao R. recently finished building her house.   Presently, it is the time to pay for the construction cost.  However, her personal savings are insufficient to make this possible. In order to deal with this situation, she is applying for a loan from Kiva to add to her savings to pay for the construction cost.

loans.use: To pay for construction cost of home

loans.name: Handsuren

texts.en:
Handsuren is married and lives with her husband and her youngest son in their own house in a Darhan, the second largest city of Mongolia. Her husband is a truck driver and used to work for a transportation company for 8 years. Handsuren started her meat-selling business in a local market with a starting capital of 2,000- 3,000 MNT in 1995. Her business has grown quickly over the years and she has gained much experience as a businesswoman. Her earnings have enabled her to build a winter house and buy a truck, so that her husband and youngest son could operate their transportation business. Thanks to their business and endless effort, three of her four children have attended University and gotten their degrees. Now they are all married and able to take care of their families by themselves. Handsuren's dream is to open her own grocery store by her house because she thinks that it would be difficult to stand out at the stall all day for an older woman. The members of this family are all hardworking, honest and effective people who could use the bank loans successfully and improved their quality of life and pay the loan back on time. Handsuren is requesting a 2,000,000 MNT to purchase more meat that she could sell and make more money during Tsagaan Sar, Mongolian Traditional New Year. She is eager to expand her business and increase her money to own a grocery store near her house. 
"

loans.use: To purchase more meat

loans.name: You

texts.en: You K., 66, and a widower, is a professional tailor, making US$3 each day in TaK. province. He has been doing this job since 1990. Currently, he lives with his three children, who are working in construction and a garment factory, earning an income of US$4 to US$5 each. You K. is asking for a loan of US$1000 to purchase a tailor stand at the local market. Running a tailor stand at the market will earn more money than working from home.

loans.use: To purchase a tailor stand.

loans.name: Pring

texts.en: Pring O., 34, raises chickens and ducks in Takeo province. She is married and has three children living at home to support. Her husband works in construction, typically making US$7 per day. Pring O. is asking for a loan of US$750 to build a kitchen room.

loans.use: To build a kitchen room.

loans.name: Tuya

texts.en:
Tuya is married and lives with her husband and two children in Darhan, Mongolia's second largest city. Her husband works in repairs at the train station and supports his family. Their children go to a local secondary school.

Tuya operates a grocery trading business. She had worked as a salesperson at a local supermarket for 10 years before she started her grocery trading business at the largest trading center in her town in 2008. After a while, she moved her stall to a more crowded spot, where her sales have increased a lot. When she started operating her business, her working capital was 1,500,000 MNT and after 2 years of successful operations she has managed to increase her working capital to a level exceeding over 3,000,000 MNT.

Since she has a stall with a very good location, she wants to continue her grocery trading business. Therefore, Tuya is requesting a 3,000,000 MNT loan to expand her business and increase the inventory of the grocery to sell during the Tsagaan Sar, Lunar year celebration of Mongolians. She says "Once I have my own stall, there're not much difficulties in running such business. More goods will bring more income".

loans.use: To increase grocery inventory.

loans.name: Lim

texts.en: Lim K., 52, is a widowed farmer who lives with her two children in Takeo province. She typically makes US$2 each day and would like to increase her profits. The weather conditions have been difficult in Cambodia this past year and inflation has also been out of control. These factors have played into a difficult economic year for many Cambodians, Lim K. included. She is asking for a loan of US$1200 to purchase fertilizer for the farm, and raise pigs.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer and raise pigs.

loans.name: Ven

texts.en: Ven S., 57, is a widow with two children living at home in Takeo province. She works in a grocery store, typically making US$5 each day and one of her children works in a local hotel, making an income of US$5 per day. To earn more money, Ven S. is asking for a loan of US$500 to raise cows for sale.

loans.use: To raise cows.

loans.name: Fe

texts.en:
Fe G. is from the village of Balingasag, Misamis Oriental. She is 36 years old, married, and has 5 school-aged children. To make a living, Fe owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from buying and selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap, canned goods, junk food, biscuits & toothpaste in the local community. Fe has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Fe joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Fe has successfully repaid a previous loan of 11,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional inventory and working capital. Fe is requesting a new loan of 14,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell like junk food and canned goods. This loan will be the 4th loan taken out by Fe from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell like junk food & canned goods.

loans.name: Sonya's Group

texts.en:
It’s amazing to see people who find courage to be optimistic when they face many struggles. Some cope with it thanks to the support of close ones, some with the help of personal beliefs, and some by using their faith. 

Sonya B., 54, is a leader of this group. She is one of those people who, in spite of harsh conditions, push forward and look for a bright spot in a seemingly dark future. Sonya and her husband, a construction worker, step by step built their own home and gave birth to four sons and a daughter. Unfortunately, the oldest boy was born with innate physical disabilities, and needs special care and treatment and constant attention. But Sonya was not discouraged by the illness of her son, and she started looking for ways of assisting her husband financially. She chose private entrepreneurship, because it’s the most profitable option for her.

In 2007, Sonya saved some money to purchase a couple of heads of cattle. She had to remember her skills from her youth. Year by year Sonya was blessed with success and achieved some good results in cattle breeding. In three years she managed to increase the size of the cattle stock dramatically. Now the business generates at least 5,000 soms monthly. Sonya applied for a loan in order to purchase additional cattle and keep her stock big and healthy. 

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: To purchase cattle.

loans.name: Violeta

texts.en:
Violeta B. is from the village of Jasaan, Misamis Oriental. She is 44 years old, married, and has 4 adult-aged children. To make a living, Violeta owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from buying and selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap, canned goods, junk food & toothpaste in the local community. She also buys and sells coconut wine or tuba. Violeta has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Violeta joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Violeta has successfully repaid a previous loan of 12,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional inventory and working capital. Violeta is requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell like canned goods & junk food. This loan will be the 4th loan taken out by Violeta from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell like canned goods & junk food.

loans.name: Aigul's Group

texts.en:
Our next creditor combines such vitally important skills as the ability to fully enjoy life and feel fulfilled. She has a big stimulus for doing it.  

Aigul M., 38, is a leader of this group.  Despite her young age, Aigul already is a proud mother of eight children, the oldest one of whom is 21. Aigul admits that having such a big and united family is the main and most important accomplishment for her. She tries to develop a strong sense of family ties in every one of her children. Aigul’s oldest son and daughter are currently in Russia. This country provides better employment and earnings, rather than their motherland. Her children do their best to take part in helping with the family budget, because it requires a lot of expenses to raise their younger siblings. Aigul herself has been breeding livestock for 22 years already. Having such a long experience brings its own fruits. Aigul is faster and more effective than most of her competitors. When the livestock is ready for sale, Aigul goes to a local market in a village of Ozgorush, where she performs her entrepreneurial skills. Her monthly profit is only 2,000 soms, not much for such a big family. Aigul now hopes to get a loan to purchase more livestock and resell it successfully.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: To purchase livestock.

loans.name: Lutfiya

texts.ru: Ниёзова Лутфия проживает в районе Варзоб. Ей 45 лет. Замужем, имеет 5 детей. Высшего образования не имеет. Четыре года как занимается животноводством. Она в основном разводит скот в дальнейшем для продажи. Кредит берет для закупа скота.
texts.en: N. Lutfiya lives in the Varzob region. She's forty-five years old, married and has five children. She doesn't have a university education. For the past four years she has bred animals for sale. N. is asking for a loan in order to buy some cattle.

loans.use: To purchase cattle

loans.name: Sari Pertiwi Group

texts.en:
Ni Luh K. is chairman of the group Sari Pertiwi. With this new loan, she plans to buy 3 pigs and food for the pigs. Currently, the price of pig food is quite expensive, therefore she mixes feed with traditional food made from leaves.
Pig farming businesses are a reliable means to support the income of families in Indonesia. The advantage of this effort can cover the needs in the kitchen, school fees and needs of children during the holiday.

loans.use: Piglets and feed

loans.name: Felomina

texts.en:
Felomina U. is from the village of Claveria, Misamis Oriental. She is 52 years old, married, and has 4 adult children. To make a living, Felomina owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from buying and selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap, canned goods, junk foods, biscuits & toothpaste in the local community. Felomina has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 7,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Felomina joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Felomina has successfully repaid a previous loan of 11,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional inventory and working capital. Felomina is requesting a new loan of 13,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell like canned goods & junk food. This loan will be the 4th loan taken out by Felomina from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell like canned goods & junk food.

loans.name: Monaliza

texts.en:
Monaliza G. is from the village of Waterfall, Balingasag, Misamis Oriental. She is 42 years old, married, and has 2 school-aged children. To make a living, Monaliza owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from buying and selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap, canned goods, junk foods, biscuits & toothpaste in the local community. Monaliza's husband has a motorela or habal-habal (transportation) services. Monaliza has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 12,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Monaliza joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Monaliza has successfully repaid a previous loan of 12,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional inventory and working capital. Monaliza is requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell like junk food & canned goods. This loan will be the 4th loan taken out by Monaliza from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell like junk food & canned goods.

loans.name: Gulmira's Group

texts.en:
Even a small amount of loans from Kiva can make a big difference in somebody’s life. Helping someone else on the other part of a planet is a good way to make our world a little bit better than yesterday.

Gulmira N., 39, is a leader of this group. She is a resident of the small town Uzgen, Southern Kyrgyzstan, which is well-known for its special type of brown rice. Gulmira owns a small shop which offers consumer goods of all kinds. Customers from all over the neighborhood know her very well and shop at Gulmira’s shop with pleasure. She has been doing it for 10 years already, so she knows goods that are valued by customers and which are not.

Gulmira is married and has two daughters. Her husband and the oldest daughter are at this moment in the Russian Federation, where they work and contribute some earnings to the family capital. Income generated from the running of a shop is usually spent on buying wholesale goods and equipping the shop. Gulmira is satisfied with how her business is operating, because thanks to many years of savings and persistent work, her family built a new house. As the number of residents in her neighborhood grows and inflation causes higher expenses, Gulmira had to apply for a loan in hopes of increasing the goods circulation and improving the standards of living of her family.  

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: To purchase home products for sale.

loans.name: Joselito

texts.en:
Joselito D. is from the village of South Cogon, Misamis Oriental. He is 45 years old, married, and has 4 adult children. To make a living, Joselito owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from buying and selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap, canned goods, junk food, biscuits & toothpaste in the local community. He also sells electronic loads of several networks like GLOBE & SMART. Joselito has been engaged in his business for over 10 years and earns approximately 9,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Joselito joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Joselito has successfully repaid a previous loan of 11,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional inventory and working capital. Joselito is requesting a new loan of 14,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell like canned goods & junk food. This loan will be the 4th loan taken out by Joselito from HSPFI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand his business.

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell like canned goods & junk food.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase sacks of cashew nuts for resale.

loans.name: Pedson

texts.en: Pedson is a forty-nine year old married man with six children who owns a house in Kasese, Uganda. He has been in the tailoring business for the last eight years which he started by selling plain clothes (Bitenge) and later acquired capital and bought sewing and design machines. His hardship includes debtors, plus high fees for rent and electricity. His vision is business expansion and educating his children. Pedson intends to use the loan to buy clothes to sell.

loans.use: To buy clothes to sell.

loans.name: Nelson

texts.en: Nelson is a thirty-nine year old married man with six children and he owns a house in Kasese, Uganda. He has been a farmer for the last ten years. He started with two sacks and now has thirteen sacks of coffee. His hardships include pests and diseases and low harvest. His vision is to process and export the best quality coffee to an increased market, plus educate his children. Nelson needs the loan to purchase farm equipment.

loans.use: To buy farm equipment like a pruner and a spraying pump.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase a bundle of wheat flour, sugar, cowpeas and coconuts.

loans.name: Bakytbek's Group

texts.en:
Sculptures from times of Soviet period and of Kyrgyz Independence period made by famous Kyrgyz sculptors and architects can be seen in most of the city parks of Kyrgyzstan. Our following creditor is very unique, because he creates pieces of art.

Bakytbek K., 42, is a member of this group. Being inspired by successful people and historical events, Bakytbek always felt comfortable expressing his emotions in clay. Sculptures have been his passion since early childhood, when he used to make figures from sand on the beach at Lake Issyk Kul. He tried working on monuments and plates with inscriptions, and realized he could turn his hobby into a business.

To Bakytbek’s surprise, this business started developing at a high pace. Now he has orders almost every day and is quite busy. Seven years have brought good results. At this moment Bakytbek earns 7,000 monthly, which supports his wife and four children financially. The purpose of his applying for a loan is to purchase raw materials for accomplishing more orders from customers. Bakytbek is very thankful to lenders, because it gives him the opportunity to express his inner world and make a living through his favorite occupation.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: To purchase raw materials.

loans.name: Anarkan's Group

texts.en:
Many small businesses are hard to start, but turn out to be a success when a person demonstrates good entrepreneurial skills, hard work and decision making abilities. As time goes on, experience helps an entrepreneur to be more effective, efficient and fast.

Anarkan A., 48, is a leader of this group. A resident of a small town Toktogul, she is married and has three children. It’s been three years since she, her husband and their younger son have been working in cattle breeding and reselling. Anarkan’s husband is a driver, and despite the fact that it takes a lot of time and energy, he still does his best to help out with the family business.

Anarkan herself is a consultant in a local central library. She has always enjoyed being surrounded by an aura of education and knowledge. She had to work part-time to save up for cattle breeding. The business was started three years ago with the purchase of three heads of cattle for 10,000 soms. It had been a lot of pressure, because much of the savings and a lot of hope was put into this business. It is paying off, bringing in 2,000 soms monthly. Anarkan says it’s not enough for some personal purchases such as furniture. She hopes to get the loan and repay it according to schedule. 

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: To purchase furniture.

loans.name: Costina

texts.en:
Costinah N. is thirty-five years old and married. Her husband is an office clerk and they have one child aged five years old whom they hope to give a quality education to the university level. Her business is located at Trans-Ami and she is served by the Kitengela branch. She owns a store in which she sells such items as stoves, pans, buckets, cups, flasks and other items to the local people.

She has been in this business for the last year and has managed to give employment to one person. She says that this business is profitable and the major challenge she has is there are so many people doing the same kind of business as hers in the area and so customers are not loyal as they are spoilt for choice. However, she works very hard to keep her business doing well. She is using her loan of Kes 20,000 to add stock to grow the business and meet the demands of her customers. She hopes to be a wholesaler in future. She describes herself as innovative, business oriented, and ambitious.

loans.use: To buy flasks, bowls, plates, buckets, etc.

loans.name: Alicia

texts.en:
Alicia A., 56 years old, is married with 5 kids. Alicia owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector planting and harvesting rice for sale. She works hard to provide her family with a better standard of living. Alicia plans to start a backyard piggery to have an extra source of income.

Alicia is in need of additional seeds and fertilizers. She has applied for a loan of 20,000 PHP from Kiva partner, CEVI. She will also use part of the loan to buy piglets to raise. She is hopeful that this loan will help improve her harvest.

loans.use: To buy seeds, fertilizers and piglets to raise.

loans.name: Tima

texts.en:
Tima is a married woman with three children, two of whom attend school while one is still too young for school.  She owns a house that neither has electricity nor piped water.  Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees.

For the past ten years, she has operated a food stall business, selling at the market to her neighbours and passersby.  Tima faces a major challenge of competition from other food stall operators.  She hopes to expand in the future.

With the 35,000 KES she wants to purchase sacks of rice, beans, sugar and wheat flour.  She decided to work with Yehu to access loans to improve her livelihood.

loans.use: To purchase sacks of rice, beans, sugar and wheat flour.

loans.name: Gemma

texts.en:
One woman that strives for beauty in life is Gemma V..  Being a Community Partner in CCT*, Gemma strives to make her business a reflection of beautiful progress.  At age 35, she rears four children who are in elementary and high school studies with her husband Dionisio, a driver.  Their family resides in Caloocan City.

Gemma has been running a sari-sari (variety) store of her own for three years now.  She sells products that are sought after by members of her community on a daily basis, such as sachets of seasonings, canned goods, and cold beverages.  Also, she manages to keep a manicure and pedicure business, which really sells among women in her neighborhood.  With these entrepreneurial efforts, Gemma earns around 4,750 PHP per month.

To sustain these efforts and help her grow her business, Gemma would like to request for a 9,000 PHP loan.  She will use this money to adorn her store with products that catches the eye of both regular and potential customers.  Gemma makes sure that every product she sells will be worth every centavo of her customers' money.  Part of the money will also be used in her manicure and pedicure business.

Admittedly, Gemma finds it hard to do business now that prices are high.  She knows that she cannot simply increase the prices of her retail products because her customers will be affected.  But with the loan money on hand, she will be able to buy in bulk in order to be able to purchase the products at a cheaper cost.  Gemma desires to have her own commercial space for her manicure and pedicure business, which will probably grow into a beauty parlor.  But beyond the physical growth of her business, Gemma desires to see her children graduate from college, because for her, education is one of the most beautiful things a parent can give her children.

As CCT community partner, she faithfully attends their weekly fellowship* meeting where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she received.
	
*All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners.  The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: Restocking inventory of variety store.

loans.name: Bernie

texts.en:
Bernie is a married man with a 2-year-old son.  He owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising rice crops.  He says the farm has been very helpful to his family and he hopes for it to grow more.  His wife maintains a small piggery in their backyard.  He works hard for the future of his son.

Bernie is in need of additional piglets, feeds and farm inputs.  He has applied for a loan of 8,000 PHP from Kiva partner, CEVI.  He is hopeful that this loan will help improve his business.

loans.use: To purchase additional piglets, feeds and farm inputs.

loans.name: Suhbaatar

texts.en:
Suhbaatar is 29 years old, married, and lives with his wife and a child in Arhangai, a central province in Mongolia. His wife is a dressmaker and his baby infant stays at home. He started operating a taxi service in his town using his car, in 2007. He transports local residents to and from various points in his province and has his regular customers. At first, he started his business with a starting capital of 80,000 MNT and today his working capital exceeds 400,000 MNT. He continues to work as a taxi driver and wants to upgrade his car and make more money.  With increased income he could help his wife to open her own comfortable workshop and buy a sewing machine. They would like to provide the opportunity for their child to get a good education in the future.
Suhbaatar is a calm and sociable person who gets along with others easily. His wife fully supports his business and agrees with the idea to get a loan to improve their living and fulfill their dreams. Therefore, he is requesting a 700,000 MNT loan to buy necessary spare parts for his current car and a sewing machine for his wife.  



"

loans.use: To buy necessary spare parts

loans.name: Ernesto

texts.en:
Ernesto Orizonto, 41 years old, is married and has 5 kids. His eldest is 25 years old, while the youngest is 11. He owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector planting and harvesting rice crops. He and his wife sell his harvest at the market. His wife also maintains their small piggery in their backyard. Ernesto works hard to support the studies of his kids.

Ernesto is in need of additional piglets, feed and farm implements. He has applied for the loan of 5,000 PHP from Kiva partner, CEVI. He is hopeful that this loan will help him improve his business.

loans.use: To purchase additional piglets, feed and farm implements

loans.name: Michelle

texts.en:
The desire to help does not depend on one's circumstances. Our CCT* Community Partner, Michelle F., 27, does not emphasize the fact that she is in need, but seeks first to help others meet their own needs. Michelle is a single parent. She reached college, and with her current business she raises three dependents.  One child is already in elementary school, and two are not studying yet. Her family resides in Caloocan City.

Michelle buys and sells clothes in the Ready To Wear (RTW) business. She sells clothes like shirts and pants to her business connections and friends. Also, Michelle sees a future in selling peanut butter, which she makes herself. This business is a hit primarily because Michelle gets the taste that favors the appetites of her customers. Monthly, Michelle is able to earn an estimated net income of around Php10,500.

To help her continue the operation of her business, she requests a Php15,000 loan. She will add this loan to the money she currently has in order to purchase more clothes and accessories, as well as ingredients for peanut butter, sugar and peanuts.

She recognizes that exhaustion keeps her down and becomes her major struggle, but she is determined to overcome the tiredness mentality, get enough rest everyday, and grow her business. She sees her business as a way to help her family and her community. Her hope is to give her children a bright future, and one step toward that is to be able to send them to school, up to college.
