*All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To purchase ingredients for peanut butter-making, and apparel to sell

loans.name: Jermelito

texts.en:
Jermilito A., 47 years old, is a married man from Surallah, South Cotabato. He owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector planting and harvesting rice for sale. He also maintains a small piggery in his backyard. He works hard to improve his family's living conditions. 

Jermilito is in need of piglets, feed, and seeds. He has applied for a loan of 15,000 PHP from Kiva partner, CEVI. He is hopeful that this loan will help him improve his business and harvest.

loans.use: To purchase piglets, feed, and seeds

loans.name: Suhbaatar

texts.en: Suhbaatar, 31, is married and lives with his wife and 2 children in the Arhangai province, in central Mongolia. His son goes to a local elementary school, and the daughter hasn't yet reached school age. His wife is a photographer, but she helps her husband's business. They have been residing at their permanent place for 4 years. Suhbaatar has been operating his family-based vegetable trading business since 2006. His starting capital was 300,000 MNT and his working capital is about 3,000,000 MNT today. He always pays attention on his business and buys the vegetables to replace the varieties that he runs out of. His family members support and make contributions to his business as much as they can. The members of this family are all in good physical condition and able to run the business further. As a result of their business and endless effort, they were able to buy a car. Suhbaatar, who is a hardworking and sociable vegetable trader, says that his current  business is the source of their family income and wants to expand it in order to provide his children with a good education. Suhbaatar is requesting a 2,800,000 MNT to buy more vegetables to expand his business.

loans.use: To buy more vegetables

loans.name: Marvin

texts.en:
Marvin C. is from the village of Batangan, Valencia City, Bukidnon. She is 21 years old. Marvin is single. To make a living, Marvin owns & operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from buying and selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap, canned goods, snack foods, biscuits, detergents & toothpaste in the local community. Marvin has been engaged in her business for over 2 years and earns approximately 12,000 PHP a month for these activities. Marvin's name sounds like a name of a man but Marvin is a woman.

In 2009, Marvin joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Marvin has successfully repaid a previous loan of 21.000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. Marvin is requesting a new loan of 25,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell like snack foods & canned goods. This will be the 7th loan taken out by Marvin from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell like snack foods & canned goods

loans.name: Ma. Fe

texts.en:
38 years old, Ma. Fe A. is married and has two children. Ma. Fe owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector planting and harvesting rice for sale. She also grows pigs in their backyard. When she is not busy tending the farm and piggery, she sells fish at her town's market. Ma. Fe does all these activities to help provide for her family's needs.

Ma. Fe is in need of seeds, fertilizer and piglets. She has applied for a loan of 8,000 PHP from Kiva partner, CEVI. She is hopeful that this loan will help her improve her business.

loans.use: to purchase farm inputs and piglets

loans.name: Elsa

texts.en:
This is Elsa D. C., 45, resident of Pasay City, Philippines. She is married to Rommel D. C., a salesperson, and mother to their only child. By the grace of God, Elsa has managed to support her child’s schooling. At this time, she is working hard to be able to send her child all the way through college--a dream for most Filipino parents like Elsa as she herself has been a college undergraduate and believes that a college diploma is the best inheritance parents could leave to their children.

Elsa operates a food stall. In the Philippines, the whole working community and most families only eat home-cooked meals in the evening where all of the family members are at home to take part in the meal. This is not only a usual family tradition but a matter of convenience and frugal living. It is considered a waste of money and time to use cooking gas and raw food for one to two persons when buying cooked rice and viands costs less than raw food. Elsa's regular customers are her neighbors and the local community.  She earns a minimum of Php 200 in sales every day.

To help her continue operation of her business, she is requesting a Php 12,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy meats, rice, vegetables, condiments and seasonings. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.  

Elsa dreams of having her own house soon. She also hopes that her business will mature and be successful. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship members to share stories of her work every week.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: buy more meats, rice, vegetables, condiments and seasonings

loans.name: Salvacion

texts.en:
Salvacion S. is a business-minded and a very innovative mother for she always thinks about how to improve not only their business but also their living conditions. She has been a good mother to their children and a good leader for her group. She is 44 years old and married to a very responsible and humble husband Nestor Angel S. who is also known for being a public servant.

As of now they still have 6 dependents; some of these are still studying and taking college degree courses. She wants all of their children to finish their studies, and to become financially stable and to have good health.

Moreover, she is an active  member of ASHI-ASB, though some of her group mates have a repayment problem; she was never affected by it and instead she really works hard in order to fulfill her obligations and maintain her good performance. 

Because of her good performance, she took out a bigger loan from ASHI. While her loan has increased, her business is also improving. As of now she is planning to put up a restaurant in their vacant lot at Bantayan, San Jose Antique. In order to realize these dreams she needs PHP.49,000 which will serve as start-up capital for her business. She chose this business because she wants to have additional income, to make use of her talents and expertise in cooking, and to help other people in the community by providing employment.

Despite challenges and frustrations some people never give up because they wante to reach their dreams and aspirations, not only for their family but also to help people in the community.

loans.use: Restaurant

loans.name: Florina

texts.en:
Florina M. is from the village of Bantuanon, Lantapan, Bukidnon. She is 47 years old. Florina is married and has 6 adult children. To make a living, Florina owns & operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from buying and selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap, canned goods, snack foods & toothpaste in the local community. Florina has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 15,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Florina joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Florina has successfully repaid a previous loan of 17,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. Florina is requesting a new loan of 21,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell like canned goods and snack foods. This will be the 6th loan taken out by Florina from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell like canned goods & snack foods

loans.name: Mwanamisi

texts.en:
Mwanamisi is a married woman with two children, both of whom attend school. She owns a house that has electricity but not piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

For over ten years, she has operated a retail shop business, selling to her neighbours and passersby. Mwanamisi faces a major challenge of competition from other retail shop operators.  She hopes to expand her business in the future.

With the Kshs 40,000 she wants to purchase bundles of wheat flour, maize flour, sugar, tea leaves, cooking oil, rice, peas and kerosene for resale. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to improve her livelihood.

loans.use: To purchase bundles of wheat flour, maize flour, sugar, tea leaves, cooking oil, rice, peas and kerosene for resale

loans.name: Arlene

texts.en:
This is Arlene R., 49, resident of Pasay City, Philippines. She is married to Nelson R., a painter, and mother to their children, all of whom stay at home managing the household and helping her with the business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses.

Arlene operates a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store, which retails groceries, toiletries and beverages piecemeal to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, a Php5-worth of cooking oil, or an egg. Arlene earns by getting supplies at wholesale prices and selling by the piece.  Her store is located adjacent to her house. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community.  She earns a minimum of Php 400 in sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a Php 22,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.  

Arlene dreams of being able to renovate her house soon, with all of her work with the business. She also hopes to enlarge her current place of business and her product inventory. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: buy groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory

loans.name: Albina

texts.en:
Albina U. is from the village of Poblacion, Lantapan, Bukidnon. She is 46 years old. Albina is married and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Albina owns & operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from buying and selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap, canned goods, snack foods, biscuits, detergents & toothpaste in the local community. Albina has been engaged in her business for over 15 years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Albina joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Albina has successfully repaid a previous loan of 12,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. Albina is requesting a new loan of 20,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell like canned goods & snack foods. This will be the 6th loan taken out by Albina from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell like canned goods & snack foods

loans.name: Remedios

texts.en:
Remedios M., 51 years old, is married to a farmer. She has five beautiful daughters and one son. Remedios helps her husband maintain their farm. She also helps in selling their harvest to people in their community. Remedios also finds time to grow pigs in their backyard. She fattens the pigs and sells them at the market. Remedios wishes for her family to have better living conditions.

Remedios is in need of additional piglets, feed and seeds. She has applied for a loan of 15,000 PHP from Kiva partner, CEVI.

loans.use: to purchase farm inputs and piglets

loans.name: Margaret

texts.en:
Margaret is a 45-year-old married lady.  She is blessed with an eleven-year-old child who goes to school. She has been operating a chemist's shop for the past six years.  She was previously employed in a hotel.  Since she joined Faulu Kenya, she has been able to meet her financial obligations. 

She hopes to expand her business into wholesale in the future.  She has requested 80,000 Kes to expand her business premises and buy medicines and cosmetics.

loans.use: To expand her business premises and buy medicines and cosmetics.

loans.name: Rowena

texts.en:
Rowena C. is from the village of Bantuanon, Lantapan, Bukidnon. She is 46 years old. Rowena is married and has 4 adult children. To make a living, Rowena owns & operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from buying and selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap, canned goods, snack foods, biscuits & toothpaste in the local community. She also buys and sells beverages & cell phone electronic loads for several networks like SMART & GLOBE. Rowena has been engaged in her business for over 2 years and earns approximately 14,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Rowena joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Rowena has successfully repaid a previous loan of 15,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. Rowena is requesting a new loan of 20,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell like canned goods & snack foods. This will be the 6th loan taken out by Rowena from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell like canned goods & snack foods

loans.name: Anita

texts.en:
This is Anita T., 41, resident of Pasay City, Philippines. She is married to Frederick, a warehouse man, and together they have two school-aged children and two who stay at home managing the household and helping her with the business. By the grace of God, Anita has managed to support her children's schooling, hopefully up to college level. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses.

Anita operates a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store, which retails groceries, toiletries and beverages piecemeal to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go for to buy one sachet of shampoo, a Php5-worth of cooking oil, or an egg. She earns by getting supplies at wholesale prices and selling piece rate.  Her store is located adjacent to her house. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community.  She earns a minimum of Php 300 in sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a Php 21,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.  

Anita dreams that all of her children will be able to finish their studies one day and have stable jobs. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: buy groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory

loans.name: Ma. Salvacion

texts.en:
Ma. Salvacion A. has been an active member of ASHI- ASE since 2006. Ma. Salvacion is 33 years old and comes from District 3, Sibalom, Antique, Philippines. She is married to Eduardo A. Jr., an electrician, and she has been a good mother for her three children.

They earn a living through appliance repair, so this is also her project. Her loan from ASHI serves as their business capital. Her loans really help them to continue the project and to provide good and fast service to their clients because they have their own rolling capital entrusted to them by the institution.

Throughout almost 4 years of membership in ASHI, Ma. Salvacion has maintained her good performance as a member and also a leader in their center. She has been chosen as a nominee for outstanding member of the branch and she is one of the members who access bigger loans through ASHI.

As of now, she has successfully paid off her loans through ASHI and she is proposing PHP 25,000 for her next loan. The family dreams of improving their business, so that they will have a bigger income to address the increasing needs of the family and for preparation for the future of their children.

loans.use: Electronic Repair

loans.name: Khurshed

texts.ru: Шарипов Хуршед житель района Хамадони. Ему 33 года. Женат. Имеет 4 детей. Образование - среднее. Зарабатывает путем разведения крупнорогатого скота. Он разводит скот у себя дома. У него имеются условия для продвижения своего бизнеса. В этой области уже три года. Кредит берет для закупа крупнорогатого скота.
texts.en: Khurshed S. lives in the region of Hamadoni. He is 33 years old. He is married and has four children. He has secondary education. He makes his money by breeding large cattle. He breeds the cattle at home. He has the means to develop his business and has been in this field for three years. He is taking out the loan to buy large cattle.

loans.use: To buy large cattle

loans.name: Elvira

texts.en:
Elvira C. is from the village of Poblcion, Lantapan, Bukidnon. She is 40 years old. Elvira is married and has 4 young children. To make a living, Elvira owns & operates a small general store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from buying and selling daily use products such as instant noodles, food seasoning mix & yellow or sweet bananas in the local community. She is also making and selling snacks like Filipino pastry named 'binangkal'. Elvira has been engaged in her business for over 2 years and earns approximately 8000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Elvira joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Elvira has successfully repaid a previous loan of 12,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. Elvira is requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell like snack foods & canned goods. This will be the 4th loan taken out by Elvira from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell like snack foods & canned goods

loans.name: Mwanasha

texts.en:
Mwanasha is a married woman with one child who has graduated from school. She owns a house that has electricity and piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

She operates a poultry business, selling from home to her neighbours and restaurant operators. Mwanasha faces a major challenge of seasonality in her business. She hopes to increase the number of chicks to at least 1000 in the future. 

With the Kshs 30,000 she wants to purchase chicken feed. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to improve her livelihood.

loans.use: To  purchase chicken feed

loans.name: Susan

texts.en:
This is Susan D. S., 55, resident of Pasay City, Philippines. She has two children, both of whom are already enrolled in college and are living at home helping her manage the household and run the business. By the grace of God, Susan has managed to support her children's schooling up to college level. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses.

Susan operates a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store, which retails groceries, toiletries and beverages piecemeal to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go for to buy one sachet of shampoo, a Php5-worth of cooking oil, or an egg. She earns by getting supplies at wholesale prices and selling piece rate.  Her store is located adjacent to her house. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community.  She earns a minimum of Php200 in sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a Php 28,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 
 
Susan dreams that her children will be able to finish their education soon. She also hopes that her business will continue to grow. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship members to share stories of her work every week.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: buy groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory

loans.name: Ainysh's Group

texts.en:
Ainysh M. is the leader of this group. She is 58 and married to a taxi driver. Together with her husband she has raised three sons and two daughters. The older children are working in Russia, and the youngest son breeds cattle to earn money. Two years ago, with the initial investment of 10,000 soms, the family started to breed cattle. Reselling cattle after fattening, they earn 6000 soms per month. That profit has made it possible for them to save money to purchase a vehicle. With money received from the loan, Ainysh wants to purchase more cattle for breeding. In the future she wants to purchase equipment to open a bakery.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase cattle

loans.name: Angelina

texts.en:
Angelina M. is from the village of Bantuanon, Lantapan, Bukidnon. She is 40 years old. Angelina is separated from her spouse and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Angelina owns & operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from buying and selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap, canned goods, snack foods, milk powder, coffee, eggs, detergent & toothpaste in the local community. Angelina has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 8000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Angelina joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Angelina has successfully repaid a previous loan of 11,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. Angelina is requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell like snack foods & canned goods. This will be the 4th loan taken out by Angelina from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell like snack foods & canned goods

loans.name: Vukuzenzele Group

texts.en:
Christina is 54 years old and married, with three children between the ages of 12 and 21. Two of her children attend school and her husband works in a garage fitting tires on cars. She sells curtains in Mtubatuba, a city in the province of KwaZulu-Natal, South Africa.

She has been selling curtains for a 3 years, going house to house. She has requested this first loan through WDB and Kiva to purchase more stock of curtains. She hopes that the extra income generated will help her increase her business and further her children's education. Christina is the leader of her borrower group and is pictured above in the center of the photo raising her hand.

loans.use: To buy more curtains for resale

loans.name: Enrequita

texts.en:
Enriquita M. is from Surallah. She is 64 years old and married. Her family is engaged in hog raising and farming as their means of livelihood. But as far as their capacity to create capital for their small business venture is concerned, they still lack money to acquire piglets and farm improvements, so she is applying for a loan to buy for two (2) piglets and fertilizers for her farm.

Enriquita has been working very hard to support her family. She is happy that CEVI’s program includes insurance and hospital assistance.

loans.use: To buy for two piglets and fertilizers

loans.name: Damaris

texts.en: Damaris M. is thirty-three years old and married. Her husband works in a petrol station, and they have two children, aged eleven years old and eight years old. Her business is located at Kitengela. She owns a tailoring shop and makes clothes for the local people. She has been in this business for the last four years and has one employee. She says that this business is profitable, and the major challenge she has is that so many people are in the same kind of business in her area. Customers are not loyal as they are spoilt for choice. However, she works very hard to keep her business doing well. She is using her loan of Kes 20,000 to buy materials to grow her business and meet the demands of her customers. She hopes to open a tailoring college to impart knowledge and skills to other people. She sees herself owning land on which she will build a residential house. She describes herself as honest, creative and ambitious.

loans.use: Materials

loans.name: Rocel

texts.en:
Rocel S. is thirty years old and married. He is from the village of Bantuanon, a part of the municipality of Lantapan, Bukidnon province on the Mindanao islands. Rocel runs a sari-sari (variety) shop from which he sells daily use products such as shampoo, soap, canned goods, snacks, biscuits, detergents and toothpaste to the local community. Rocel has been engaged in his business for over five years and earns approximately 8000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Rocel joined HSPFI to gain access to its financial services.  He successfully repaid a previous loan of 11,000 PHP from HSPFI that was used to purchase additional inventory and for working capital. Rocel is requesting a new loan,  of 15,000 PHP his fourth loan from HSPFI that will be used to purchase additional products to sell like canned goods and snacks. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve his business. 

About HSPFI:

Hagdan sa Pag-uswag Foundation, Inc., or HSPFI, is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that one-on-one translations of entrepreneur profiles are costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow it to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Fatuma

texts.en:
Fatuma A. is a married woman with four children, all of whom attend school. She owns a house that neither has electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are school fees and food.

Fatuma runs a stall at the market from which she sells food to market dwellers and neighbors. She decided to join Yehu to access loans and improve her living standards.

With a 20,000 KES loan Fatuma wants to purchase bundles of wheat flour and sugar. She hopes to establish a restaurant in the future.

loans.use: To purchase bundles of wheat flour and sugar

loans.name: Erlyn

texts.en:
Erlyn S. is 24 years old and the mother of two girls. Her husband is a farmer in the town of Santo Niño in the province of South Cotabato on the Mindanao islands. Their main source of income comes from raising hogs and farming. She helps her husband keep the farm productive by keeping it free of weeds and pests.

Erlyn would like a loan so she can buy feed for the pigs, fertilizer and seeds. Her wishes for the future are to gain wealth through the help of loan assistance and soar far in her business ventures.

loans.use: To buy feed for her pigs, fertilizer and seeds

loans.name: Maricel

texts.en:
Maricel M. is 27 years old,  married, and has one child. She lives in the village of Lilingayon, Valencia City, Bukidnon. To make a living, Maricel owns and operates a specialized retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling ready-to-wear clothing and shoe products from NATASHA and AVON in the local community. Maricel has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 9,000 PHP a month.

In 2010, Maricel joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Maricel has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI, which was used to to purchase additional inventory and acquire working capital. Maricel is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell such as t-shirts and blouses. This loan will be Maricel's second loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell such as t-shirts and blouses

loans.name: Em

texts.en:
Em M., 60, is married and resides with her three children in Kampong Chnang province, Cambodia, an area known for palm products. M. is a housewife while two of her children are employed, earning an income of USD 2 each per day to help cover the family expenses. Each month, the family has to spend USD 55 on food and USD 10 on the other necessary expenses. 

M. is requesting a loan of USD 600 to dig a well and purchase wire to light the house. This will be her third loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva’s partner.

loans.use: dig a well and purchase wire to light the house

loans.name: Ethel Grace

texts.en:
Ethel Grace F. is married with one baby boy, one year of age. She is 27 years old and her husband is a carpenter. She raises hogs for fattening and sale. Her loan is to be used for hog raising and buying additional piglets and feed.

Her wish is for her child to finish college. She also hopes to become capable of producing many pigs so that she will be one of the big producers in their town.

loans.use: to buy additional piglets and feed

loans.name: Charles

texts.en:
Charles is a member of Kibera Upendo group in Faulu Kenya.  For twelve years, he has been making bangles in Kibera slums.  Charles is a married man with six children hence he works hard to provide for his family.  As a member of Faulu Kenya, he has been able to get capital for his business.  

He hopes to become a major supplier of his products in the future.   He has requested 20,000 Kes to buy brass wire and bench massing.

loans.use: To buy brass wire and bench massing

loans.name: Aurelia

texts.en:
Aurelia M. is from the village of Sto. Niño, Talakag, Bukidnon. She is 56 years old. Aurelia is married and has 6 children. To make a living, Aurelia owns & operates a furniture making business. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from making & selling general household furniture like beds & cabinets to local businesses and community members. Aurelia has been engaged in her business for over 18 years and earns approximately 12,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Aurelia joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Aurelia has successfully repaid a previous loan of 15,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional materials needed and as working capital. Aurelia is requesting a new loan of 20,000 PHP which will be used to purchase raw materials to make additional furniture. This will be the 5th loan taken out by Aurelia from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase raw materials to make additional furniture

loans.name: Evangeline

texts.en:
Evangeline S. is 44 years old, married, and owns a farm as their source of income. She has been blessed with four children, two boys and two girls. Their current income is not enough to support the growing needs of their family. 

When she heard about how CEVI helps small businesses, she applied for a loan to help in funding their farm. Insurance and hospital assistance are also some of the things that she liked about CEVI’s program.

loans.use: farm financing

loans.name: Seng

texts.en:
Seng N., 58, is married and resides with her two children in Kampong Chnang province, Cambodia, an area known for palm products. 

N. and her husband produce traditional baskets to sell, earning an income of US $2.5 per day to help cover the family expenses. Each month, the family has to spend US $63 on food and $45 on the other necessary expenses. 

N. is requesting a loan of US $700 to purchase a plot of farmland to expand the family farming. This will be her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner.

loans.use: To buy a plot of farmland to expand the farming business

loans.name: Evelyn

texts.en:
Evelyn M. is a 30-year-old mother of two children. Her children are both in school. Evelyn is engaged in a hog-raising business, which she started seven years ago. Evelyn sells the pigs that she grows. 

She applied for a loan of 4,000 PHP from CEVI. She will use it to acquire vitamins, feed and other needs of her piggery.

She wishes to send her children to college, have a stable business and to be financially capable in the future.

loans.use: To buy for vitamins, feed and other supplies

loans.name: Jessica

texts.en:
Jessica O. is from the village of Sto. Niño, Talakag, Bukidnon. She is 35 years old. Jessica is married and has three school-aged children. 

To make a living, Jessica owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop, selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap, canned goods, snack foods, beverages and toothpaste in the local community. Jessica has been engaged in her business for over eight years and earns approximately 12,000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Jessica joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her business and living situation. Jessica has successfully repaid a previous loan of 17,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional inventory and for working capital. 

Jessica is requesting a new loan of 20,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell like canned goods and snack foods. This will be the fifth loan taken out by Jessica from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the loan to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:
HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To pay laborers to consolidate sand for resale

loans.name: Um

texts.en:
Um N., 31, is married and resides with her two children in Kampong Chnang province, Cambodia, an area known for palm products. 

N. is a farmer, earning an income of US $2 per day. Her husband sells charcoal and firewood for an income of US $7 per day to help cover the family expenses. Each month, the family has to spend US $44 on food and  $35 on the other necessary expenses. 

N. is requesting a loan of US $1,000 to purchase a mechanical plow to help plow the rice field. This will be her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner.

loans.use: To buy a mechanical plow to help plow the rice field

loans.name: Tserennadmid

texts.en: Tserennadmid, 36, is widowed and lives with her three children in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. She and her children live together in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic home tent. All her three children attend school. Tserennadmid operates a clothing trading business to support her family. She started her business in 2003 by selling a variety of clothing items out of a rented space in Narantuul, the main and largest outdoor market in the city, with the help of her husband. Her husband passed away two years ago; therefore, she runs her business all by herself. Her business is located in a popular spot of the market that attracts many customers. She is working hard to raise her children as a single mother. Tserennadmid is requesting a 1,500,000 MNT loan to import more clothing items from Erlian, a border city of China.

loans.use: To import more clothing items

loans.name: Geraldine

texts.en:
Geraldine F., 38 years old, is married to a farmer. She has two children, a girl and a boy. Her husband makes extra income by driving a motorcycle transporting people in their place. To help sustain their family, Geraldine raises pigs that she fattens and sells to the market. She also helps her husband maintain their rice farm. Geraldine works hard for the needs of her family.

Geraldine is in need of additional fertilizers, seeds and pig feed. She has applied for a loan of 6,000 PHP from Kiva partner, CEVI.

loans.use: To buy additional fertilizers, seeds and pig feed

loans.name: Cristy

texts.en:
Cristy L. is from the village of Dalirig, Manolo Fortich, Bukidnon. She is 30 years old. Cristy is married and has five school-aged children. To make a living, Cristy owns & operates a business making and selling coconut wines or tuba in the local community. Cristy has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 12,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Cristy joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Cristy has successfully repaid a previous loan of 11,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional inventory & working capital. Cristy is requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase raw ingredients like coconut sap needed to make products for sale. This loan will be the fourth loan taken out by Cristy from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale like coconut sap

loans.name: Marn

texts.en: Marn K., 38, is married and resides with her three children in Kampong Chnang province, Cambodia, an area known for palm products. K. sells groceries, earning an income of USD 7 per day. Her husband grows rice to sell for an income of USD 2 per day to help cover the family expenses. Each month, the family has to spend USD 63 on food and USD 50 on the other necessary expenses. K. is requesting a loan of USD 500 to purchase more groceries to stock the store. This will be her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner.

loans.use: To buy more groceries to stock the store

loans.name: Edward

texts.en: Edward is 45 years old and the father of seven children. He lives with his family in Hioma, Uganda, and his dream is to be able to educate his children. For the past 25 years, Edward has been running a carpentry and joinery business. His biggest business challenge is the lack of capital and his hope is to have his own workshop space. He is requesting a loan to build a two-room workshop for his carpentry business.

loans.use: to build a workshop

loans.name: Sith

texts.en: Sith M., 25, is married and resides with her two children in Kampong Chnang province, Cambodia, an area known for palm products. M. is employed at the garment facotry, earning an income of USD 3 per day. Her husband is employed as a construction worker for an income of USD 3 per day to help cover the family expenses. Each month, the family has to spend USD 53 on food and USD 35 on the other necessary expenses. M. is requesting a loan of USD 450 to purchase a plot of farmland to improve the family farming. This will be her first loan from CREDIT, a long standing Kiva partner.

loans.use: To buy a plot of farmland to improve the family farming

loans.name: Imee Love

texts.en:
21-year-old Imee Love is from Sto. Niño, South Cotabato. At a young age, Imee Love is already married and has a one-year-old child. Imee is engaged in farming. She and her husband till their land together to plant and harvest rice crops. They also have some vegetables planted in their backyard. Imee works hard for her child's future.

Imee is in need of additional capital for the farm. She has applied for a loan of 10,000 PHP from Kiva partner, CEVI. She is hopeful that this loan will help her maintain their rice farm.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Levie Joy

texts.en:
Peanuts once said, “Nothing takes the taste out of peanut butter quite like unrequited love.” Well, with all the love and passion Levie Joy D., 36, receives and gives in her life, this statement does not quite apply to her. Levie is loved by her husband Ruben, a factory worker whose primary work is to make peanuts. They live together in Tala, Caloocan City. With all the passion Levie Joy invests in her business, there’s nothing that will make life bitter for her.

Just like her husband, Levie is also into the peanut butter making business. She makes peanut butter that sells profitably in her community. Levie applies what she learns from CCT* as a Community Partner to make her business work. Every month she earns around 6,000 PHP.

Because Levie knows she needs some financial help for her business, she has decided to request a loan for 20,000 PHP. She will use most of this money to buy essential ingredients like peanuts, sugar, and salt. Part of the loan will go to meet the family's immediate needs such as payment of the electricity bill.

Levie recognizes that the hot weather and exhaustion do keep her from functioning productively at work. But she is determined to find ways to overcome these struggles and give her full potential in developing her business. She looks forward to owning a complete set of materials for peanut butter making, which will undoubtedly boost her entrepreneurial pursuit. But more than the material achievement, Levie desires to help her community. No unrequited love is known by Levie, as she is loved by her family as much as she loves them and desires to give them a good future.

For now, Levie faithfully attends her weekly fellowship* meeting in CCT where she draws strength and inspiration from the Word of God she received and from the testimonies and real life stories being shared by her fellowship group co-partners.

*All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to purchase peanut butter making materials

loans.name: Temtsel

texts.en:
Temtsel is 25 years old and lives with his wife and child in the Arhangai province in Mongolia. He and his family live in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. Temtsel operates a animal rawhides trading business in his town. He purchases products from local herders and uses his own car to transport and sell raw materials to local suppliers for a profit. Temtsel started his business in 2009, with the working capital of 500,000 MNT. Within a short period of time, he has established a stable business in his local community and increased his capital to 1,200,000 MNT. 

In 2008, Temtsel purchased a car to transport his products. He is a modest and hardworking man who is requesting a 500,000 MNT loan to purchase animal rawhides and increase his sales.

loans.use: to purchase animal rawhides

loans.name: Marites

texts.en:
He who opens a school door, closes a prison, Victor Hugo says. Marites M., 44, believes so, and knows further that children are our country's hope. Her value of education enabled her to reach college. She is now married to Danilo, a driver, and together they raise a child who is now a college student.

Marites runs a day care school and through it, she provides education to the young kids in her community. Also, she sells Ready To Wear (RTW) clothes to business connections and friends. Having been in business for 10 years at present, she quite knows the needs of her customers, particularly those of the students in her day care school. Providing these services, she gets to earn an estimated net income around PHP 10,500 every month.

To help her provide the needs of her day care school, Marites is requesting a PHP 32,000 loan. She will use this to buy necessary school supplies and other school needs. Also, she will use this money to help her pay the school bills. Her RTW business will also benefit from this loan.

Marites does not deny that there are times when the mothers of students in her school do not pay on time. But because she knows the high value of education, she will not give up just because of her present struggles. Her dream for her school is for it to have elementary levels from Grade 1 to 6. 

As a CCT community partner, she allots one hour to attend their weekly fellowship* meeting.  This is where Marites can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she receives and from the testimonies and real life stories shared by her co-partners among the fellowship group.

*All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To do further furnishing of the day care school

loans.name: Utushike Group

texts.fr: Masika Maombi J.  est entrepreneur, trésorière du groupe Utushike, âgée de 51 ans, mariée, mère de 6 enfants.  Son conjoint est chômeur, sans emploi. La cliente Masika Maombi J.  est vendeuse des  souliers plastics  localement appelés bodaboda  à son domicile et  au long de la rue ambiante. Elle  commença son business  avec son fonds propre reçu de son mari. Avant de joindre cette activité, jadis, elle vendait ambulante des arachides  dans le lieu public, dans les rues commerciales, dans les hôtels, au café resto-bars, etc. Son capital d’affaire fut 100$. Plus tard, elle bénéficia le premier crédit de l’IMF Hekima de 50$ au début de  2010. Ce nouveau crédit doit lui servir de s’approvisionner  avec  des nouveaux produits (20 pairs de souliers, 5 pièces des pagnes à revendre, etc.).  En plus, elle ambitionne voir ses enfants  finir leurs études. La cliente Masika Maombi  J.  remercie Hekima pour  ses actions en faveur de pauvres exclus de banque classique. Le groupe Utushike est constitué de 26 membres. Cette photo fut prise à l’intérieur de la chapelle qui leur sert de lieu des réunions d’affaire.
texts.en: Masika Maombi J. is an entrepreneur, the treasurer of Utushike Group, 51 years old, married and the mother of six children. Her husband is unemployed. Our customer Masika Maombi J. sells plastic shoes (called "bodaboda" in the local language) from her home and along the street. She began her business with working capital that she had received from her husband. Before starting this trade, she was a street peddler, selling groundnuts in public space, shopping streets, hotels, cafés, restaurants, snack bars, etc. Her initial working capital amounted to $100. Later, early 2010, she was granted a loan of $50 by the microfinance institution Hekima. She will use her new loan to buy new merchandise for sale (20 pairs of shoes, 5 units of pagnes, etc.). She told us that her goal is to see her children finish their studies. Our client Masika Maombi J. thanks Hekima for supporting poor people excluded from the traditional banking system. Utushike Group is composed of 26 members. This photo was taken in the chapel, where the group has its business meetings.

loans.use: To buy 20 pairs of shoes and 5 units of pagnes

location.country: The Democratic Republic of the Congo

loans.name: Nov

texts.en:
Nov M., 25, is married and resides with her child in Battambong province, Cambodia, an area known for quality rice products. M. sells lotus flowers, earning an income of 4 USD per day. Her husband sells lotus flowers for an income of 3.5 USD per day to help cover the family expenses. Each month, the family has to spend 45 USD on food and 35 USD on other necessary expenses.

M. is requesting a loan of 700 USD to purchase more lotus flowers to resell. This will be her first loan from CREDIT, a longstanding Kiva partner. M. appears in the middle of the photograph where she is preparing lotus flowers to sell.

loans.use: To buy more lotus flowers to resell

loans.name: Sem

texts.en:
SE. E., 41, is married and resides with her three children in Battambong province, Cambodia, an area known for quality rice products. E. and her husband are construction workers, earning an income of 3 USD each per day. Each month, the family has to spend 90 USD on food and 60 USD on other necessary expenses.

E. is requesting a loan of 700 USD to purchase a motorbike for the family to use. This will be her first loan from CREDIT, a longstanding Kiva partner.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike for the family

loans.name: Lonah

texts.en:
Lonah S. is a married lady who has six children aged between seventeen and thirty years old. Her business is located in Kakamega, the region in Kenya known for its production of sugarcane and commonly known as the sugarbelt region. She owns a grocery shop in which she sells vegetables, fruits, yams, arrow root, etc. She describes herself as humble, intelligent and focused.

Lonah says her business is profitable but that the major challenge she faces is the low purchasing power of the people in the area. Since she sells perishables, she must work to ensure all her items are bought quickly, which is not very easy sometimes.

Lonah is requesting a loan of 20,000 KES to buy more potatoes and fruits to meet the demands of her customers. She hopes to grow her business and see her last-born child through their education in the future.

loans.use: To buy more potatoes and fruits

loans.name: Batzorig

texts.en: Batzorig is 24 years old and lives with his wife and daughter in Hentii province in Mongolia. He and his family live together in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. His wife stays at home taking care of their infant daughter while Batzorig supports his entire family by operating a welding service in his town. He started his business in 2007 and has since built a stable operation with many permanent customers. Over the many years, he has gained a lot of experience as a welder who is very popular among his customers. With his business earnings, which are the only source of his family income, he has improved his family's standard of living. Batzorig is a hardworking and honest person. He is requesting an 830,000 MNT loan to purchase a new welding machine for his business.

loans.use: To purchase a new welding machine

loans.name: Mwanasha

texts.en:
Mwanasha is a married woman with four children. One of her children has graduated from school, two are still in school, and one is still too young. Mwanasha owns a house without electricity or potable water and her greatest monthly expense is food. 

For over ten years, Mwanasha has operated a cashew business, selling to her neighbors and passersby. Her major business challenge is seasonality. Mwanasha decided to join Yehu to access loans and improve her livelihood. She is requesting a loan of 20,000 KES to purchase cashew nuts. In the future, Mwanasha hopes to become a reliable coconut seller.

loans.use: to purchase cashew nuts

loans.name: Mugoma Farmers Group

texts.en: Robert is a 27-year-old married man with two children living in his own house in Fort Portal, Uganda. The responsibility to take care of the family solely rests on him and his family dream is to build a permanent residential house. He has a retail shop, which he has operated for 10 years after saving money from alcohol brewing. His desire is to set up a wholesale shop in town. He is a member of Mugoma Farmers group where each member guarantees the other member's loan. Robert needs the loan to buy salt, sugar and paraffin to sell.

loans.use: To buy salt, sugar and paraffin to sell.

loans.name: John Joy

texts.en:
John Joy R. is 38 years old and married with a nine-year-old child. He is a farmer who plants and harvests rice and pineapples on his land. He also runs a sari-sari (variety) store and a T-shirt printing shop. John Joy wants to provide a good living for his son and wife.

John Jay is in need of additional farm inputs and merchandise to sell. He has applied for a loan of 6,000 PHP from the Kiva partner, CEVI. He is hopeful that this loan will help his business grow.

loans.use: to purchase farm inputs and merchandise

loans.name: Prisca

texts.en:
Prisca A. is 63 years old.  She is from Kisumu county.  She is a widow who is taking care of her five children. Most of her children have grown up – the first-born is 40 years old and the last is 25 years old.

She is in the business of selling dry fish in Winam market. She is currently applying for her second loan to enable her buy more fish to add to her stock. Prisca is in an area where fish is a delicacy and this has helped her get many customers. Her monthly income is 40,000 KES.

Prisca's desire is to be able to buy a piece of land and build a home for orphans.

loans.use: To buy dry fish to sell

loans.name: Ismat

texts.en: Ismat is a mother of six children: four daughters and two sons. Ismat and her husband are employees with a decent salary. Therefore, they have decided to start a business that would add to their income and secure a better life and education for their six children. Ismat and her husband started a small animal farm that is growing slowly. To enlarge the farm, they took out a loan from FATEN to purchase more goats to raise to produce milk and make cheese to sell. Ismat's husband appears in the picture here, as she is a conservative woman.

loans.use: To purchase more goats to enlarge the farm

loans.name: Turakhon

texts.ru: Бобоев Турахон проживает в районе Хамадони. Возраст, 57 лет. Женат. Имеет 7 детей. Жена, домохозяйка. Сам Турахон занимается торговлей. У него имеется продуктовый магазин в селе Маргоб. Этим видом бизнеса он занимается уже 5 лет. Кредит берет для увеличения товарооборота.
texts.en: Turakhon B. lives in Hamadoni Region. 57 years of age. Married, with seven children. His wife is a homemaker. Turakhon is in retail business. He keeps a grocery store in the village of  Margob. He has been in this business for five years. He is taking out a loan to increase his sales volume.

loans.use: Increasing sales volume

loans.name: Jomelyn

texts.en:
Forty-one-year-old Jomelyn is married and has a beautiful daughter. They live in Sto. Niño, South Cotabato. Jomelyn plants and harvests rice. Part of her harvest is used for family consumption and the rest is sold to the market. Jomelyn works hard for her daughters’ future.

Jomelyn is in need of additional seeds and fertilizer. She has applied for a loan of 6,000 Philippines pesos (PHP) from CEVI. She is hopeful that this loan will help improve her harvest.

loans.use: To purchase additional seeds and fertilizer

loans.name: Peter Sankale

texts.en:
Peter Ngasahr is 23 years old.  He is married to Cynthia. They have one baby, who is three months old.  He lives with his family in the Ololchani area in Kilgoris.

Peter is a farmer and has been in this business for the past three years. He has seen his business grow after he took out the first loan.  He is now applying for the second one to enable him buy bean seeds and fertilizer to use on his farm. 

Peter has a good credit history with us and earns a monthly income of Kes 40,000. The profits made from the harvest will be used to expand the business by investing back into it.

His dream is to be able to buy a Nissan bus that can be used for a transport business.

loans.use: To buy bean seeds and fertilizer

loans.name: Lorna

texts.en:
Lorna L., 46 years old, is a married woman from the town of Santo Niño in South Cotabato province on the Mindanao islands. She has six children: four girls and two boys.

Lorna is a farmer who plants and harvests rice crops. She also has banana trees planted on her land. Lorna rents a stall at the market to sell her harvest. That way, she has access to more people in the market for rice. Lorna works hard to provide for the needs of her family.

Lorna is in need of additional fertilizer and seeds. She has applied for a loan of 10,000 PHP from CEVI. She is hopeful that this loan will help improve her harvest.

loans.use: To purchase seeds and fertilizer

loans.name: Tarcisia

texts.en:
As Sophocles said, no man loves life like he who is growing old. At 61, Tarcisia O. cannot have loved life more. Tarsing, as she is called by family and friends, did not even manage to finish high school, but has gone far in life. At present she attends fellowships in CCT as a Community Partner and enjoys the company of her grandchildren as she lives in Bagong Silang, a barangay of Caloocan City located on the islands of Luzon.

Tarsing sells vegetables, meat, fish, and fruits to the community and has become an advocate for healthy eating by doing so. She starts early in the morning, offering products that are fresh and healthy. Every month, she earns an estimated net income of around 10,000 PHP.

To help her grow her business, Tarcisia is requesting a 15,000 PHP loan. She plans to use this to buy more fresh supplies of meat and vegetables as well as fish and fruits. She will make sure that her products are not only fresh, but that they are also varied so as to allow more options for her customers. Tarsing also intends to add frozen foods to her goods for sale.

As a local vender, Tarsing feels the weight of exhaustion and lack of sleep. Nevertheless, she is always ready to serve her fellow community members by offering and encouraging them to buy healthy foods. She wants her business to become well established and have more regular customers. She looks forward to abundant blessings from the Lord so that she may be able to help her grandchildren.

As a CCT community partner, she faithfully attends their weekly fellowship meetings where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she receives.

About CCT:

The Center for Community Transformation (CCT) is an organized Christian response against poverty and social injustice. This is carried out through the fusion of social development initiatives and evangelical missionary work in a uniquely Filipino context. It serves urban and rural poor communities throughout the Philippines in pursuit of its desire to see changed lives, strong families, and transformed communities centered in the Lordship of Jesus Christ. CCT is a member of the Five Talents family.

Locally, all CCT community partners and clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To purchase more fresh vegetables, fruits and fish to sell

loans.name: Marcelina

texts.en:
Marcelina C. is a married woman who has two children, one girl and one boy. She is a farmer who plants and harvests rice and vegetables. She also grows pigs in her backyard. She fattens the pigs and sells them at the market. She works hard to provide healthy living for her two precious kids.

Marcelina is in need of additional seeds, fertilizer and pig feed. She has applied for a loan of 4,000 PHP from Kiva’s partner, CEVI.

loans.use: To purchase seeds, fertilizer and pig feed

loans.name: Moses

texts.en:
Moses Z. is a young married man with a one-year-old child. He runs a motorcycle repair business in Kakamega, a region in Kenya known for the production of sugarcane and commonly referred to as the sugarbelt region. Along with repairing motorcycles, Moses also sells tires and spare parts. This business is profitable for him but his major challenge is the lack of financial capital. 

Moses works very hard from early morning to late evening to keep his business doing well. He is requesting a loan of 40,000 KES to buy spare parts to expand his business and meet customer demand. Moses describes himself as determined and focused. In the future, he hopes to expand and have a big auto and spare part shop.

loans.use: to buy spare vehicle parts

loans.name: Joseph Mutema

texts.en:
Joseph has been practicing farming in Ndunyu Njeru town for the last two years.  He is 62 years old and is married to Annah Wangechi.  They have two children.

He was introduced to KADET LTD by his friend.  This will be his second loan.  He repaid his first loan of Kshs 20,000 well and in good time.  He plans to use this new loan amount to buy fertilizer and pesticides for his farm.

In the future, Joseph hopes to continue with farming and become one of the leading farmers in Ndunyu Njeru town.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and pesticides for farm

loans.name: May Vynn

texts.en:
36-year-old May Vynn R. is single and living with her parents. She is into the hog-raising business. She also runs and manages a sari-sari store where she sells different products. May Vynn also sells her harvest of cassava from her garden. She works hard to help her parents provide the increasing needs in their household.

May Vynn needs hog feed, vitamins and additional merchandise to sell. She has applied for a loan of 8,000 PHP from Kiva partner CEVI.

loans.use: To purchase hog feed, vitamins and additional merchandise to sell

loans.name: Fred

texts.en:
Fred is a 35-year-old married man with four children. He lives in his house in Fort Portal, Uganda. He stays in a rented house and his dream is to build his own permanent house in the next four years. 

For six years, he has been in motorcycle transport. He started as an employee, but later bought his own motorcycle. His ambition is to buy a car for a taxi business. Fred intends to use the loan to buy a motorcycle.

loans.use: Buying a motorcycle

loans.name: Hajiri

texts.en:
Hajiri is a married woman with three children, two of whom attend school while one is still too young for school. She owns a house that has electricity but not piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees. 

She has operated a food-stall business for the past three years, selling from home to her neighbors and passersby. Hajiri faces a major challenge of seasonality in her business. She hopes to increase sales and get more income in the future. 

With the 20,000 Kenyan shillings, she wants to purchase bundles of wheat flour, rice and sugar. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to improve her livelihood.

loans.use: To purchase bundles of wheat flour, rice and sugar

loans.name: Helina Njoki

texts.en:
Helina has practicing mixed farming in Ndunyu Njeru town for the last 20 years.  She is 47 years old and is a single mother of five children.

She was introduced to KADET LTD by her friend.  This will be her second loan.  She repaid her first loan of Kshs 20,000 well and in good time.  She plans to use the new loan amount to buy a dairy cow.

In the future, Helina hopes to practice large scale farming and produce high quality products from her farm.

loans.use: To buy a dairy cow

loans.name: Sonia

texts.en:
Married with kids, Sonia B. works hard to be the best wife and mother she can be. She wakes up early in the morning to prepare food on the table then goes straight to their farm with her husband. Sonia helps plant and harvest rice crops. She also helps in selling their harvest. 

Sonia needs farm inputs, such as seeds and fertilizers. She has applied for a loan of 8,000 Philippines pesos (PHP) from Kiva partner CEVI. She is hopeful that this loan will help improve her harvest.

loans.use: To purchase farm inputs, such as seeds and fertilizers

loans.name: Bolormaa

texts.en: Bolormaa is 39 years old and lives with her husband and adult son in Hentiy province in Mongolia. She and her family live in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. Her son attends university while her husband works as a carpenter for a local company. Bolormaa operates a clothing trading business out of a rented stall at the local market in her town. She has been engaged this business since 2003 with her own working capital. With her business earnings, she has afforded to pay her son's tuition fees. She plans to increase her working capital for her clothing business. Bolormaa is a clever and hardworking person and is requesting a 800,000 MNT loan to purchase more products for her business.

loans.use: To purchase more products

loans.name: Consejo

texts.en: Consejo V. is from the town of Sto. Niño. She is 46 years old. Consejo is married and has two children, aged 15 and 13. To make a living, Consejo plants and harvests rice for sale. Consejo joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Consejo has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. Consejo is requesting a new loan of 8,000 Philippines pesos (PHP), which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. This will be the second loan taken out by Consejo from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve it. About CEVI: Community Economic Ventures, Inc., (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over recent years. Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines. In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring. CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but also offers savings, insurance, and training programs, which are provided through regular cluster group meetings. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers such as manure

loans.name: Hannah Hati

texts.en:
Hannah had practised farming in Ndunyu Njeru town for the last four years. She is 46 years old, married to Remmi Mohamed and they have three children.

She was introduced to KADET LTD by one of our field officers and this will be her first loan. She plans to use the loan amount to buy fertilizer and seedlings for planting.

In the future, Hannah hopes to practice large scale farming and increase her income.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and seedlings for planting.

loans.name: Byambasuren

texts.en: Byambasuren is 40 years old and lives with his wife and three children in Ulaanbaatar, a capital city of Mongolia. He and his family live in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic housing tent. His wife works as a public inspector for the district's government agency. Byambasuren operates a taxi service in the city using his own car. He started his own business in 2007 by transporting a variety of loads in the Huchit shonhor market, one of the largest markets in the city. Today, he drives a taxi after selling his big truck and purchasing a small car. In addition, he operates a welding service to supplement his earnings. For the future, he plans to build a big house with fence for his family. He is requesting a 800,000 Mongolian tugriks loan to purchase necessary spare parts for his car that is used as a taxi.

loans.use: To purchase necessary spare parts

loans.name: Carlito

texts.en:
Carlito G. is a farmer. He is married and is living in the town of Sto. Niño, South Cotabato. His friends describe him as a kind person. Carlito also enjoys what he does. He says he is very thankful for his rice farm because it helps his family in a lot of ways. Carlito works hard to improve his farm and earn more for his family. 

Carlito applied for a loan from CEVI. He will use it to buy fertilizers and other materials needed for a good harvest.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers and other farming materials

loans.name: Nimbwera

texts.en:
Nimbwera is a married woman with two children, both of whom attend school. She owns a house that has electricity but not piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food. 

She has operated a vegetable-stall business for the past two years, selling from home to her neighbors and passersby. Nimbwera faces a major challenge in the price fluctuation of vegetables in her business. She hopes to increase sales by supplying vegetables in the market.

With the 20,000 Kenyan shillings, she wants to purchase sacks of vegetables for resale. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: To purchase sacks of vegetables for resale

loans.name: Rehema

texts.en:
Rehema M. K. is 30 years old. She is married to a hotelier and has two children, aged 4 and 11 years. Her business is located at Magongo estate in Mombasa, Kenya. Mombasa is the coastal region of Kenya and is well-known for its many many tourist-attraction sites, not forgetting the Indian Ocean's white beaches. 

She has been selling fruits and vegetables for the last two years to the local people. She says that this business is profitable and the major challenge she has is there are so many people doing the same kind of business as hers in the area and so customers are spoiled for choice. However, she works very hard to keep her business doing well. 

She is using her loan of 40,000 Kenyan shillings to buy more fruits and vegetables to expand her business and meet the demands of her customers. She hopes to grow her business and stock cereals as a wholesaler in the future. She also hopes to give her children a quality education. She describes herself as customer-friendly.

loans.use: Fruits and vegetables

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy fertliser and pesticides for his farm.

loans.name: Joseph

texts.en:
Joseph is a 40-year-old married man with three children. He is living in a semi-permanent house in Fort Portal, Uganda, with a dream of educating his children up to university.

He has been in a taxi business for five years, and the business has enabled him to provide basics to the family. His hardship is limited capital; his dream is to own at least two taxis. Joseph needs the loan to buy tires for his car

loans.use: Buying tires

loans.name: Chuluunbaatar

texts.en: Chuluunbaatar is a 30-year-old single man who lives with his sister in Ulaanbaatar, a capital city of Mongolia. He and his sister's family live in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic housing tent. Chuluunbaatar operates a taxi service in the city using his own car. Before starting his business, Chuluunbaatar used to live in the countryside as a herder in the Bayan-Ulgii province.
